sage.app

Class BaseGame

  • java.lang.Object
    • sage.app.AbstractGame
      • sage.app.BaseGame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEventListener

    public class BaseGame
extends AbstractGame
implements IEventListener
    BaseGame provides an implementation of all the methods specified in AbstractGame, except that the initGame() and update(float) methods are empty stubs. A user can thus create a simple game by writing a class which extends BaseGame and overrides the stubbed initGame() and update(float) methods, and then invoking the (provided) start() method.

    The provided start() method invokes the provided initSystem() method to create a default output system (display and renderer), invokes the user-provided initGame() method, and then enters a main loop which repeatedly invokes a (provided) handleInput(float) method, followed by invoking the user's update(float) method and then the (provided) render() method.

    It is the responsibility of the user's update(float) method to invoke super.update(float), passing to it a time parameter, if the geometric position of game world objects is changed in the user's update(float) method. Note that invoking super.update(float) should be done after making changes to the game world object geometry.

    It is the responsibility of the user's initGame() method to create any desired input actions and associate them with input devices so that they are invoked by BaseGame's handleInput(float) method. The user's initGame() method should also construct the game world to be displayed, by creating SceneNodes defining gameworld objects and adding them to the game world using addGameWorldObject(SceneNode). It is also the responsibility of the user's code to indicate when the game is over, by invoking setGameOver(boolean) either directly in the user's update() method or indirectly within an input action registered with BaseGame's InputManager.

    Author:
    John Clevenger
    See Also:
    IAction, InputManager.associateAction(net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier, IAction, sage.input.IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE)

      Consumes an event of type IGameEvent.
      protected void handleInput(float time)
      handleInput() processes device input events, including invoking actions associated with those events.
      protected void initGame()
      initGame() performs game-specific initialization, such as defining gameworld objects, setting up scoring rules, creating objects for HUD displays, etc.
      protected void initSystem()
      initSystem() initializes the system platform for game operations, including such things as creating the display, rendering, and input manager subsystems.
      boolean isGameOver()
      Returns true if the game has been terminated by a call to setGameOver(true).
      protected void mainLoop()
      mainLoop() executes the "main loop" of a game, by repeatedly invoking AbstractGame.handleInput(float), AbstractGame.update(float), and AbstractGame.render() until AbstractGame.isGameOver() returns true.
      protected boolean removeGameWorldObject(SceneNode obj)
      removeGameWorldObject() the specified SceneNode object from the game world managed by the BaseGame class if the object exists in the game world.
      protected void render()
      render() is invoked to cause the current game world to be rendered on the current display device.

      void setInputManager(IInputManager inputManager)
      Sets the IInputManager used by BaseGame to be the specified IInputManager.
      protected void shutdown()
      shutdown() is invoked to notify the game application that the game is ending and that it should release all held resources.
      void start()
      start() is the entry point for every game; it should be invoked from main() to begin the game.
      protected void update(float time)
      update() updates the game world state, including updating player and non-player characters, performing physics simulations, and all other functions required to advance the logic state of the game.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BaseGame

        public BaseGame()

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        start() is the entry point for every game; it should be invoked from main() to begin the game. Every implementation of start() should invoke AbstractGame.initSystem(), AbstractGame.initGame(), and then AbstractGame.mainLoop(), followed by invoking AbstractGame.shutdown() and AbstractGame.exit() after AbstractGame.mainLoop() returns.
        Specified by:
        start in class AbstractGame

      • initSystem

        protected void initSystem()
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        initSystem() initializes the system platform for game operations, including such things as creating the display, rendering, and input manager subsystems.
        Specified by:
        initSystem in class AbstractGame

      • createDisplay

        protected void createDisplay()
        createDisplay() creates an IDisplaySystem for use by the game, assigning it to the global variable DisplaySystem.getCurrentDisplaySystem(). This method is invoked by initSystem(); subclasses may override this method and create their own IDisplaySystem, provided the overriding method assigns the created IDisplaySystem by calling setDisplaySystem(IDisplaySystem).

      • createInputManager

        protected void createInputManager()
        createInputManager() creates an IInputManager for use by the game, assigning it to the protected variable inputManager. This method is invoked by initSystem(); subclasses may override this method and create their own IInputManager, provided the overriding method assigns to inputManager a reference to the created IInputManager.

      • createGameWorld

        protected void createGameWorld()
        createGameWorld() creates an (empty) game world for use by the game. This method is invoked by initSystem(); subclasses may override this method and create their own game world, provided the overriding method assigns the created game world by invoking setGameWorld(ArrayList). The current implementation of BaseGame requires that the game world be of type ArrayList; future implementations will implement this in a type-transparent way.

      • initGame

        protected void initGame()
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        initGame() performs game-specific initialization, such as defining gameworld objects, setting up scoring rules, creating objects for HUD displays, etc.
        Specified by:
        initGame in class AbstractGame

      • mainLoop

        protected void mainLoop()
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        mainLoop() executes the "main loop" of a game, by repeatedly invoking AbstractGame.handleInput(float), AbstractGame.update(float), and AbstractGame.render() until AbstractGame.isGameOver() returns true.
        Specified by:
        mainLoop in class AbstractGame

        Description copied from class: AbstractGame

      • update

        protected void update(float time)
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        update() updates the game world state, including updating player and non-player characters, performing physics simulations, and all other functions required to advance the logic state of the game. update() is responsible for invoking AbstractGame.setGameOver(boolean) to indicate when the player has invoked a command to end the game.
        Specified by:
        update in class AbstractGame
        Parameters:
        time - The time since the last call to update()

      • render

        protected void render()
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        render() is invoked to cause the current game world to be rendered on the current display device.
        Specified by:
        render in class AbstractGame

      • setGameOver

        public void setGameOver(boolean isOver)
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        setGameOver() is invoked to notify the rest of the application that the game is over and the application should shut down and exit. setGameOver() is normally invoked from within AbstractGame.mainLoop() when the player executes a command indicating the game is over.
        Specified by:
        setGameOver in class AbstractGame
        Parameters:
        isOver - - a boolean indicating that the game is over when true
        See Also:
        AbstractGame.mainLoop()

      • isGameOver

        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        Returns true if the game has been terminated by a call to setGameOver(true).
        Specified by:
        isGameOver in class AbstractGame
        Returns:
        - the current game-over flag state

      • addGameWorldObject

        protected void addGameWorldObject(SceneNode obj)
        addGameWorldObject() adds a SceneNode object to the game world managed by the BaseGame class. SceneNodes in the game world will automatically be rendered by the BaseGame on each iteration of BaseGame's gameloop. Note that objects added to the game world may be any of the subclasses of SceneNode -- for example, any of the SceneNode subclasses described in package sage.scene.shape.
        Parameters:
        obj - -- the SceneNode object to be added to the game world.

      • removeGameWorldObject

        protected boolean removeGameWorldObject(SceneNode obj)
        removeGameWorldObject() the specified SceneNode object from the game world managed by the BaseGame class if the object exists in the game world.
        Parameters:
        obj - -- the SceneNode object to be removed from the game world.
        Returns:
        true if the object was found and removed; false if the object was not found in the game world.
